etymologies: late Middle English; earliest use found in Sir Gawain and the Green Knight. From Anglo-Norman vealtrer, vealterer, veltrier, veutrer, feutrer person in charge of a pack of hounds from Old French veltre, viautre hound + -ier

definitions: A person who looks after and manages hunting dogs. Also more widely: an attendant. Sometimes with prefixed defining word, as fox-fewterer, yeoman-fewterer.
